Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the Open Source Systems 2016 Doctoral Consortium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding will support attendance by approximately 4 promising graduate students from U.S. institutions of higher learning at a doctoral consortium (workshop) to be co-located with the 12th International Conference on Open Source Systems, May 30 through June 2, 2016, in Gothenburg, Sweden. Students will be selected through a competitive open call, with attention paid to developing a diverse group of attendees. Students in the consortium will have a day of focused discussion of their research topics with other students and distinguished research faculty as mentors, followed by attendance at the conference to further deepen their engagement with current research and active researchers.

The last two decades have witnessed a tremendous growth in the interest and diffusion of Free/libre and Open Source Software (FLOSS) technologies, which has changed the way organizations and individuals create, acquire and distribute software and software-based services. This doctoral consortium will provide feedback to students in order to develop higher quality and more relevant research on the FLOSS phenomenon. It is often the case that only one or a few students in any particular university department will have FLOSS as a research topic, which diminishes the opportunities for these students to interact with others sharing a similar research focus. A focused doctoral consortium can be extremely beneficial to such students trying to develop and refine their dissertation research ideas. A longer-term expected benefit is the development of intellectual connections that will improve the disciplinary research that forms the students' theses, and also provide a network to support future interdisciplinary research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal supported a diverse group of US and international PhD students to participate in an series of international doctoral consortia.

The Doctoral Consortium at the 12th International Conference on Open Source Systems (OSS 2016) brought together 8 students interested in open source systems (5 women and 3 men). The Consortium was held in Gothenburg, Sweden on 30 May 2016, the day before the main OSS 2016 conference.

The Doctoral Consortium at the 13th International Conference on Open Source Systems, 2017 brought together 6 students interested in open source systems. The Consortium was held in Buenos Aires, Argentina, May 22-23, 2017, before the main conference.

The main activity of each of the consortia was discussion of the students' research. Each student presented his or her research to the entire group. Feedback was given by one lead faculty mentor assigned to that student, as well as by the other student and faculty participants, and the challenges being faced by each student were discussed. Feedback was oriented toward helping student participants understand whether their topics are adequately focused for dissertation research projects, whether their methods are correctly chosen and applied, and whether their results are being appropriately analyzed and presented.

Students had a positive evaluation of the events and felt that they had helped improve their research. Overall, the consortia helped achieve the goal of the development of a future generation of researchers grounded in their own disciplines but interested in and knowledgeable about the phenomenon of open source systems.
